item.question: What option will allow a normal user to mount a filesystem and have only the user that mounted the filesystem unmount it?
Which of the following syslog-priorities represents the highest level of importance?
What command will show the last 10 lines of a file by default?
What would be the correct command to remove the package <font face="monospace">atop</font> completely from a Debian system? Select two.
Which of the following can be used to switch your system to run level 1?

Which of the following commands gets its input from <font face="monospace">file1</font>, writes its output to <font face="monospace">file2</font> and writes errormessages to <font face="monospace">file3</font>?
What is the mountpoint of the first swap partition?

The root filesystem resides on device <font face="monospace">/dev/hda2</font>. What is the corresponding name for this device in GRUB's configuration file at the line '<font face="monospace">root (</font>_______<font face="monospace">)</font>'?
You are curious to which RPM-package the file <font face="monospace">/sbin/fdisk</font> belongs. What command do you use to find out?

When you wish to install a new application you downloaded from the internet what would be a good location on the filesystem according to the Filesystem Hierarchy Standard. Assume that you want other users to be able to use the application as well.
You received an ASCII file from a good friend of yours who uses the windows OS. You notice that you see a lot of CR-LF line endings in the file. How can you remove the CR part from the file?
You want to see detailed information of the installed package <font face="monospace">samba</font>. What RPM command would provide you this information?

You want to use shared libraries that are in <font face="monospace">/home/guru1/mylibs</font> (which is not in the standard library search path).
What is the appropriate command to use these libraries.
What would the file <font face="monospace">/etc/updatedb.conf</font> allow you to do?
item.choice: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database
Specify the time at wich the locate-database should be updated
Specify which users are allowed to use the <font face="monospace">locate</font> command
item.correct_answer: Exclude directories from being included in the locate-database

item.question: Which of the following Linux commands can be used to create backups of filesystems and directories? Select all correct answers.
When partitioning a disk with more than 1024 cylinders, which of the following could affect the systems ability to boot? Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The location of the Master Boot Record
Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk
item.correct_answer: BIOS support for the disk Location of the kernel image (<font face="monospace">/boot</font> directory) on the disk

item.question: Which utility would be used to verify the checksum of a downloaded archive file? You have downloaded an archive called <font face="monospace">atop.tgz</font>. Which command could you use to verify the checksum of the file?
Which of the following commands will create a symbolic link?
Which command can be used to determine the available space on all mounted partitions?
Considering the command <font face="monospace">dpkg</font> which of the following options are correct?
item.choice: -C searches for packages partially installed on the system
item.correct_answer: -r removes a package -l lists currently installed packages -C searches for packages partially installed on the system

item.question: Which option can be used with the shutdown command to <font face="monospace">fsck</font> on the next reboot?
You want to get the fourth line from a file. Which of the following commands would you use?
The kernelfile vmlinuz-2.6.18 is in the ________ directory. Answer: _______________
On a system that has the following uptime: What command is best used to print out system boot messages?

item.exhibit: $ chmod <font face="serif">"mode"</font> foo $ ls -l foo -rwsr-xr-- 1 you yourgroup 42 Sep 6 14:46 foo
item.question: Consider the following exhibit: Select the possible value for mode that caused the file foo to get the above permissions:

Assume your current working directory is ~ and you wish to copy the files from the homedirectory of user guru1 to the directory temp in your homedirectory. Which of the following commands will accomplish this?

Which of the following commands will create an ext3 filesystem on device <font face="monospace">/dev/hdb3</font>?
Select TWO answers.
Which of the following device names point to logical partitions?
Which run level can be used as administration mode?

Suppose you know that an application <font face="monospace">atop</font> is installed on the current system. You have examined the man and info pages for <font face="monospace">atop</font> thoroughly, but you still have an appetite for more information about <font face="monospace">atop</font>. Which of the following directories is the BEST first place to look for further documentation files?
What command will show the first 10 lines of a file by default?
What is the meaning of setting the sticky bit permission on a directory?
item.choice: all files created in the directory will belong to the same group as the directory.
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner
it can be used to temporarily lock the directory
files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.
item.correct_answer: files and directories can only be deleted by their owner, the owner of the directory, or a user with root privileges.

item.question:
You want to use <font face="monospace">vi</font>-like editing commands at the <font face="monospace">bash</font> command line editor. However, the default bash settings enable <font face="monospace">emacs</font>-like keystrokes.
How do you enable bash to recognize <font face="monospace">vi</font>-like keystrokes?
What is the result of the following command?
item.choice: You will get the shell secondary prompt
The text echo ATcomputing will be printed
item.correct_answer: You will get the shell secondary prompt

item.question: What lilo.conf parameter will mount the root file system read only on startup?
What command can be used to make init reload its configuration file?
Which of the following items are specified in the file <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>. Choose all correct answers.

item.exhibit: kapp: error while loading shared libraries: libkapp.so.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
item.question: You downloaded some software and installed it under <font face="monospace">/usr/local</font>. When you run the command it fails with the following error message: You located the file in <font face="monospace">/usr/local/lib</font>. How would you proceed to solve this issue permanently?
item.choice: Add <font face="monospace">/usr/local/lib/</font> to the variable <font face="monospace">LD_LIBRARY_PATH</font>.
Move the file <font face="monospace">libkapp.so.1</font> to <font face="monospace">/usr/lib</font>.

item.question: Consider the following piece of code that uses tabs to indent lines: What command will easily convert the tabs to 8 spaces?
Which of the following commands is implemented as a bash shell-builtin?
What is a disadvantage of using symbolic links over hard links?
item.choice: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.
A symbolic link can span different filesystems
The hard link uses the same inode as the original file, where a symbolic link has its own inode.
Removing a symbolic link does not remove the underlying file.
item.correct_answer: A symbolic link becomes disconnected from the underlying file if the file is moved.

item.question: You execute the following command: What will be the result?
item.choice: Only filenames in the user's homedir will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All directorynames will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
All filenames in the user's homedir will be printed in the terminal and any errors will be written to <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>
item.correct_answer: All filenames in the user's homedir and any errors reported by <font face="monospace">find</font> will be listed in the file <font face="monospace">list.txt</font>

item.question: You want to set a 20 second delay before your system boots to the default operating system. Which of the following command lines would do this?
What command can you use to create a link (<font face="monospace">newdir</font>) to an existing directory (<font face="monospace">existingdir</font>) in the same filesystem?

You enter a command (<font face="monospace">mycmd</font>) in <font face="monospace">bash</font> and want to redirect both standard output and standard error output to one file (<font face="monospace">mylog</font>).
Select all correct answers.
What is the maximum number of primary partitions a single harddisk can contain?
How would you set the sticky bit on a directory?

You need to install linux on a laptop with a 1.66 GHz processor, 2 GB of RAM and a 160 GB harddisk. The user made clear he wants support for suspend and hibernation. How much space on the disk would you allocate to be used as swap?
Which run level represents a power down?
Consider the following command and its permissions: Which of the following explanations are correct? Choose all that apply.
item.choice: The command cannot be executed by root as it has not the x-permission set for the user.
The command will remain in memory because it has the s-permission set which means sticky.
The command will run with root-privileges even when started by a regular user.
The command allows all users to change any password as the command will run with root-privileges
item.correct_answer: The command will run with root-privileges even when started by a regular user.

item.question: Is it possible for a regular user to mount and unmount a filesystem?
item.choice: There is no way a regular user can do this, because it is a root privilege.
Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">user</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">allusers</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.
Yes, any user can mount and unmount filesystems.
item.correct_answer: Yes, if the option '<font face="monospace">user</font>' is added to the corresponding line in <font face="monospace">/etc/fstab</font>.

item.question: On a Debian system, which file should be edited to add an extra location from which installation package files can be loaded?
During installation of the package <font face="monospace">atop</font> you encountered an error. Which command will display the package status?
What command can display the free inodes for all mounted file systems?

You started an application (<font face="monospace">myapp</font>) in the foreground.
How do you push this running application into the background without restarting the application?
item.choice: It is not possible without restarting the application.

item.exhibit: tak talk tik tok tuk tuuk
item.question: You current working directory contains the following files: What will be the result if you execute the command <font face="monospace">ls | grep 't[^o].$'</font>? Choose all that apply.
Which commands would check the integrity of a ext2 filesystem? Choose all that apply.

You want to move all directories and ONLY directories in you current working directory that start with <font face="monospace">test</font> to the directory <font face="monospace">testing</font>. What command is best to do this?
In which directory would you look to see if a USB device was correctly detected by the kernel?

Suppose user pete has created a new application atop, and copied it to the directory /usr/local/bin. On your system each user belongs to his/her own unique group. For instance, user petra belongs to the group petra and pete belongs to the group pete. You would like all the users who do not belong to the group or are owner of the application to be able to run your application. Which of the following command lines would allow the appropriate access?
